title: Building Habits Together
description: Explore how you support each other in building and maintaining positive habits.

questions.text: A positive habit I'm trying to build or maintain is...

therapeutic.rationale: Personal habit goals reveal what we're working on. Sleep/routine builders need consistency; exercise/health builders need motivation; mindfulness builders need calm; productivity builders need focus. Sharing goals invites support.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different habit goals are individual. You can each pursue your own priorities while supporting each other.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched habit goals create opportunity for shared pursuit and mutual accountability.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What habit are you currently working on? How could your partner support you?

questions.text: When you're working on a habit, I can best support you by...
choices: Joining you and doing it together
Cheering you on and celebrating progress
Giving you space and not interfering

therapeutic.rationale: Habit support styles vary. Joiners provide company; cheerleaders provide motivation; space-givers provide autonomy; obstacle-removers provide practical help. Knowing how your partner wants to be supported enables effective help.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different support preferences require learning what your partner actually needs, not assuming.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched support preferences make helping each other with habits natural.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How can you best support your partner's habits? Have you asked what they need?

questions.text: A routine I'd love for us to build together is...
choices: A morning or evening connection ritual
Weekly date nights or quality time

therapeutic.rationale: Shared routine desires reveal what couples want more of. Connection rituals build intimacy; shared exercise builds health together; date nights build intentional time; hobbies build shared identity. Naming desires helps create them.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different routine desires aren't mutually exclusive. You can build multiple shared routines over time.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched routine desires create clear direction for building something together.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What routine would you love to build together? What would it take to start?

questions.text: What helps me stick to positive changes is...
choices: Making it part of my routine

therapeutic.rationale: Change sustainability factors vary. Results-seekers need visible progress; accountability-seekers need external support; routine-makers need consistency; purpose-understanders need meaning. Knowing what works for your partner helps you support effectively.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: Different sustainability factors require different types of support. What works for you may not work for your partner.
therapeutic.whenSame: Matched factors make supporting each other's changes intuitive.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: What helps you stick to positive changes? Does your partner know this about you?

questions.text: When one of us slips on a habit, I believe we should...

therapeutic.rationale: Responses to habit setbacks reveal supportiveness. Compassion-givers normalize struggle; back-on-track types provide partnership; learners extract value; normalizers reduce shame. Healthy setback responses encourage persistence.
therapeutic.whenDifferent: All these responses support healthy habit recovery. They're complementary approaches.
therapeutic.whenSame: Shared setback philosophy creates aligned, supportive response to inevitable slip-ups.
therapeutic.journalPrompt: How do you respond when you or your partner slips on a habit? Is that response helpful?
